results_summary: Myricetin significantly increased NIS mRNA expression and iodide uptake in SW1736 cells and induced apoptosis, suggesting potential as a therapeutic agent for anaplastic thyroid cancer.
population_specificity: SW1736 anaplastic thyroid cancer cell line

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myricetin could counteract silica-induced epithelial cell senescence and pulmonary fibrosis by modulating mitochondrial function through the PPARγ-PGC1α axis.
results_summary: Myricetin alleviated silica-induced mortality, improved lung function, reduced fibrosis severity, and mitigated epithelial cell senescence by enhancing mitophagy and maintaining mitochondrial dynamics via the PPARγ-PGC1α pathway. Its efficacy was reversed when PPARγ was inhibited, confirming the mechanism.
population_specificity: Silica-induced pulmonary fibrosis mouse model and alveolar epithelial cells (AECs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the encapsulation of Myricetin (MYN) in hemoglobin nanoparticles (Hb NPs) for potential cancer treatment applications.
results_summary: The study found that Hb-MYN NPs were successfully synthesized, with a size of around 38.0 nm, and demonstrated dose-dependent apoptosis-inducing efficacy in K562 cells, though less than Hb-PTX NPs.
population_specificity: K562 cells (a human leukemia cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of myricetin in spinal cord injury (SCI) and determine if these effects were linked to LIMK inhibition.
results_summary: Myricetin showed a better interaction profile with LIMK than standard compounds, leading to reduced phosphorylated LIMK expression, decreased scar formation, and enhanced neuroprotection in an SCI rat model.
population_specificity: Rat contusion model of spinal cord injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Myricetin's potential as an inhibitor of Pseudomonas aeruginosa, focusing on its antibacterial and antibiofilm activity, as well as its impact on virulence genes.
results_summary: Myricetin showed significant antibiofilm activity, reducing biofilm biomass, exopolysaccharide, and extracellular DNA production, and downregulated virulence genes (lasI, pvdS, and rhlC). However, it was not tested for in vivo toxicity or efficacy in the zebrafish model, unlike diosmin.
population_specificity: Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacterial cultures and zebrafish embryos.
effective_dosage: Minimal inhibitory concentration range of 0.05 - 0.4 mg/mL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether loading Myricetin into silica nanoparticles (MYR@SBA-15) could improve its solubility, stability, and bioavailability, thereby enhancing its analgesic, antipyretic, and anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: MYR@SBA-15 significantly improved Myricetin's solubility and dissolution rate, reduced pain perception, regulated body temperature, and suppressed inflammatory markers by modulating MAPKs/NF-κB and COX-2/PGE-2 pathways. The nanoparticle formulation showed superior efficacy compared to raw Myricetin, particularly at 100 mg/kg.
population_specificity: Rats (inflammatory and pain models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a supplement containing myricetin (Si.Pi.Mi.) could reduce circulating ethanol and oxidative stress biomarkers in wine-drinking subjects.
results_summary: Si.Pi.Mi. reduced circulating ethanol by 33% after 120 minutes and improved oxidative stress markers, including increased total antioxidant capacity (9-12%) and decreased 8-isoprostane (22-27%).
population_specificity: Twenty wine-drinking subjects in a randomized controlled, single-blind trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intravenous myricetin (MYR) reduces the excitability of nociceptive sensory neurons in rats in response to mechanical stimulation.
results_summary: MYR significantly and dose-dependently inhibited the firing rate of SpVc WDR neurons in response to both non-noxious and noxious mechanical stimuli, with effects lasting about 20 minutes. The findings suggest MYR may reduce nociceptive transmission by inhibiting CaV channels and activating Kv channels.
population_specificity: Anesthetized rats
study_duration: Acute administration (effects observed within 5-10 min, lasting ~20 min)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating myricetin into alginate-cellulose hybrid nanocrystals (MAC-NCs) could enhance its selective proapoptotic effects on human AGS gastric cancer cells while minimizing toxicity to normal cells.
results_summary: MAC-NCs demonstrated significant selective toxicity against AGS gastric cancer cells (IC50 of 31.05 µg/mL) compared to normal endothelial cells (IC50 of 214.26 µg/mL), inducing apoptosis independently of Caspase-8 and Caspase-9. The study suggests MAC-NCs have promising potential as a selective anti-gastric cancer agent.
population_specificity: Human AGS gastric cancer cells and normal Huvec endothelial cells (in vitro).
effective_dosage: IC50 values of 31.05 µg/mL (AGS cells) and 214.26 µg/mL (Huvec cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether myricetin improves airway remodeling in asthma by activating Sirt1 and could serve as a potential new treatment.
results_summary: Myricetin reduced airway inflammatory cell infiltration, IL-6 and IL-5 production, mucus secretion, collagen fiber proliferation, and inflammatory cells in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid. It downregulated p-JNK, p-Smad3, and acetylated Smad3 proteins by activating Sirt1, with K341 identified as the main deacetylation site.
population_specificity: Ovalbumin-induced chronic asthma mouse model and RAW 264.7/3T6 cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myricetin (MRC) could mitigate arsenic-induced immune dysfunction, oxidative stress, hematological changes, and organ injuries in rats.
results_summary: Myricetin co-treatment significantly corrected arsenic-induced hematological and biochemical abnormalities, restored antioxidant enzyme activity, reduced oxidative stress, and attenuated inflammatory gene expression in hepatic and renal tissues.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to arsenic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine Myricetin's therapeutic potential in diabetic nephropathy by investigating its effects on the NOX4-NF-κB-Snail signaling pathway and epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT).
results_summary: Myricetin significantly mitigated EMT in diabetic nephropathy by inhibiting NOX4 expression, reducing ROS production, and suppressing NF-κB activation and Snail expression, leading to improved renal function and reduced tissue fibrosis in HFD/STZ-induced diabetic mice.
population_specificity: HFD/STZ-induced diabetic nephropathy mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myricetin could reduce neuronal death in Parkinson's disease models by inhibiting ferroptosis.
results_summary: Myricetin treatment reduced motor impairment, dopamine neuronal death, and α-synuclein accumulation in PD models. It also decreased ferroptosis markers (Fe2+, ROS, MDA) and increased GSH levels, effects reversed by the ferroptosis activator erastin.
population_specificity: Rats and SH-SY5Y cells (in vitro) as PD models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Myricetin on pancreatitis and its underlying mechanisms, focusing on its ability to inhibit acinar cell death and inflammatory responses.
results_summary: Myricetin ameliorated the severity of acute pancreatitis by inhibiting calcineurin activity, macrophage infiltration, and inflammatory cytokine production, while also modulating key signaling pathways like CaMKK2 and AMPK.
population_specificity: Animal models (cerulein-, L-arginine-, and PDL-induced acute pancreatitis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the mechanism and pathways involved in the neuroprotective effects of Myricetin in Alzheimer's disease models.
results_summary: Myricetin improved spatial cognition, learning, and memory in 3×Tg mice, reduced tau phosphorylation, and rescued mitochondrial dysfunction via GSK3β and ERK2 signaling pathways. It also mitigated oxidative stress and synaptic protein loss in Aβ42-treated neuronal cells and mice.
population_specificity: 3×Tg Alzheimer's disease model mice and Aβ42 oligomer-treated neuronal SH-SY5Y cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myricetin induces ferroptosis in breast cancer cells via the Nrf-2/GPX4 pathway and its potential as a therapeutic agent.
results_summary: Myricetin significantly inhibited breast cancer cell viability and colony formation, increased markers of ferroptosis (MDA, Fe2+, ROS), and downregulated Nrf-2 and GPX4. In vivo, it reduced tumor growth in mice by targeting the same pathway.
population_specificity: Female mice with subcutaneous breast tumors (4T1 cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the roles and mechanisms of Myricetin in preventing lumbar intervertebral disk degeneration (IDD) by attenuating nucleus pulposus cell (NPC) apoptosis and extracellular matrix (ECM) degradation through autophagy activation via the JAK2/STAT3 pathway.
results_summary: Myricetin treatment reduced apoptosis and ECM degradation while enhancing autophagy in IL-1β-treated NPCs, with these protective effects being limited by autophagy inhibition. In vivo, Myricetin activated NPC autophagy and alleviated puncture-induced IDD in rats.
population_specificity: Rats with puncture-induced IDD and isolated nucleus pulposus cells (NPCs) from healthy rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and mechanisms of myricetin (MC) in treating rheumatoid arthritis (RA), particularly its ability to reduce neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) and inflammation.
results_summary: MC effectively reduced NET release and alleviated inflammation in RA by inhibiting PADI4 and MPO nuclear entry, protecting DNA from decondensation. In a rat arthritis model, MC improved ankle joint histology and suppressed NET-related signaling factors.
population_specificity: Rats with induced arthritis (in vivo) and likely cell cultures (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Myricetin's potential to alleviate doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity and its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Myricetin reduced cardiac injury, oxidative stress, and apoptosis while improving myocardial energy metabolism via the AMPK pathway. It also suppressed pyroptosis and regulated glycolipid metabolism.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a myricetin oligomer-derived nanostructure could bypass the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and restore its function post-ischemic stroke while exhibiting therapeutic effects.
results_summary: The study found that the myricetin nanostructure effectively bypassed the BBB via glucose and iron transporters, restored BBB function by regulating tight junctions, and exhibited anti-inflammatory and antioxidative properties, acting as a multitasking therapeutic agent.
population_specificity: The study focused on brain endothelial cells and microglia in the context of ischemic stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myricetin could improve metabolic and reproductive dysfunction in PCOS by activating brown adipose tissue.
results_summary: Myricetin improved metabolic capacity, insulin sensitivity, and reproductive defects in PCOS mice, including normalized hormone levels, reduced cystic formation, and restored estrous cycles.
population_specificity: DHEA-induced PCOS mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myricetin induces ferroptosis in gastric cancer cells and its mechanism of action involving the NOX4/NRF2/GPX4 pathway.
results_summary: Myricetin triggered ferroptosis in gastric cancer cells by increasing malondialdehyde and Fe2+ while reducing glutathione levels. It also inhibited tumor growth in mice by modulating NOX4 expression and suppressing the NRF2/GPX4 pathway.
population_specificity: Gastric cancer cells (in vitro) and BALB/c nude mice with subcutaneous tumors (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Myricetin improves diabetic cardiomyopathy (DCM) by regulating gut microbiota and restoring gut barrier function.
results_summary: Myricetin improved cardiac function in DCM mice by reducing cardiomyocyte hypertrophy and fibrosis, increasing beneficial gut microbiota (e.g., Roseburia, Faecalibaculum, Bifidobacterium), and enhancing gut barrier integrity (higher occludin expression and goblet cell count). Fecal microbiota transplantation from Myricetin-treated mice also improved cardiac function and reduced inflammation in DCM mice.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced DCM mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify natural compounds targeting CD147 and evaluate myricetin's anti-tumor effects, particularly its synergy with cisplatin in ovarian cancer treatment.
results_summary: Myricetin showed strong affinity for CD147, downregulated its protein levels, and exhibited synergistic antitumor effects with cisplatin by suppressing FOXM1 and DDR genes, enhancing cisplatin-induced DNA damage response.
population_specificity: Ovarian cancer (in vitro and xenograft mouse models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Myricetin could inhibit ROCK1 and mitigate mesangial cell fibrosis and proliferation in diabetic kidney disease (DKD) via the ROCK1/ERK/P38 pathway.
results_summary: Myricetin effectively inhibited ROCK1, reducing mesangial cell proliferation and fibrosis in vitro and improving renal function and reducing DKD pathological markers in vivo. The effects were dose-dependent and mediated through the ROCK1/ERK/P38 pathway.
population_specificity: Diabetic kidney disease (DKD) models (in vitro and in vivo).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dose-dependent in vitro assays mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of myricetin on diabetic nephropathy (DN) and explore its potential therapeutic mechanism, particularly its role in regulating macrophage polarization via the PI3K/Akt signaling pathway.
results_summary: Myricetin mitigated DN-induced renal dysfunction and fibrosis in db/db mice, reduced kidney injury markers and inflammatory cytokines, and inhibited high glucose-induced inflammation in RAW 264.7 cells. Its protective effects were mediated through the PI3K/Akt pathway.
population_specificity: Db/db mice (a model for type 2 diabetes) and RAW 264.7 macrophage cell line.
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg or 100 mg/kg daily (in vivo), 25 mM (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a nanoemulsion of Myricetin (Myr-NE) and evaluate its anti-cancer efficacy compared to Myricetin alone in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells.
results_summary: The Myr-NE formulation significantly improved drug uptake, inhibited cell proliferation, reduced clonogenicity, and increased apoptosis in TNBC cells, with a ~2.5-fold lower IC50 than Myricetin alone. Mechanistic studies suggested enhanced efficacy via inhibition of the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway.
population_specificity: MDA-MB-231 (TNBC) cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myricetin could mitigate cardiac dysfunction induced by high fructose intake in rats.
results_summary: Myricetin improved systolic blood pressure and restored impaired cardiac adrenergic responses in fructose-fed rats. It also reduced the expression of PINK1, NF-κB, and Bax, suggesting a protective role against fructose-induced cardiac irregularities.
population_specificity: Rats fed a high-fructose diet for 15 weeks.
effective_dosage: Not specified (administered by oral gavage for the last 6 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how myricetin inhibits IL-21-mediated Tfh cell differentiation and its potential therapeutic effects in rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: Myricetin binds to IL-21, blocking its interaction with IL-21R, and reduces Tfh cell differentiation and IL-21 production in AIA mice, leading to improved clinical outcomes like reduced paw thickness and cellular infiltration. It also negatively regulates JAK/STAT signaling and Bcl-6 transcription.
population_specificity: Adjuvant-induced arthritis (AIA) mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myricetin could improve neurological recovery and inhibit neuroinflammation following traumatic brain injury (TBI) in rats.
results_summary: Myricetin significantly improved neurological function, reduced inflammatory responses, and decreased toxic microglia markers in TBI rats. It also protected learning and memory functions by lowering pro-inflammatory cytokine expression, likely via the EGFR-AKT/STAT pathway.
population_specificity: Sprague Dawley rats with induced traumatic brain injury.
effective_dosage: Appropriate doses (specific amounts not detailed) via intraperitoneal injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective effects of Myricetin against lead acetate-induced nephrotoxicity in rats, focusing on oxidative stress and inflammation.
results_summary: Myricetin at both doses (100 and 200 mg/kg) reversed lead-induced oxidative stress, inflammation, and renal dysfunction, and restored kidney tissue architecture. The high dose of Myricetin was particularly effective in mitigating nephrotoxicity.
population_specificity: Male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of myricetin on ethylene glycol-induced nephrolithiasis in rats, focusing on its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and renoprotective properties.
results_summary: Myricetin treatment significantly reduced urea, creatinine, BUN, Ca2+ ion, and oxalate levels while increasing citrate content in serum and urine. It also lowered inflammatory cytokines and MDA levels, enhanced antioxidant enzyme activities, and preserved kidney histoarchitecture.
population_specificity: Rats with ethylene glycol-induced nephrolithiasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myricetin could mitigate the IL-21-induced tumor-like phenotype in adjuvant-induced arthritis fibroblast-like synoviocytes (AIA-FLS) by targeting the ChoKα signaling cascade.
results_summary: Myricetin suppressed IL-21 receptor expression and inhibited the ChoKα signaling cascade (N-Ras, Ral-GDS, and PI3K), reducing ChoKα and PLD2 enzymatic activity. This led to decreased hyperproliferation, migration, and invasive behavior of AIA-FLS.
population_specificity: Adjuvant-induced arthritis fibroblast-like synoviocytes (AIA-FLS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiviral activity of Myricetin derivatives (MR and MRG) against the chikungunya virus (CHIKV) through in vitro and in silico analysis.
results_summary: MR and MRG demonstrated dose-dependent antiviral activity, significantly reducing viral titer and CHIKV RNA levels, with MRG showing effects at lower concentrations. Molecular docking suggested the nsP3 macrodomain as a potential target for these flavonoids.
population_specificity: In vitro cell substrates (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the mechanism by which Myricetin inhibits hUba1 and assess its potential as a cancer treatment by blocking ubiquitination.
results_summary: Myricetin binds strongly to the ATP-binding site of hUba1, inducing a conformational shift that blocks ubiquitin binding. The study also identified Myricetin analogues with promising docking scores, suggesting potential for further development as Uba1 inhibitors.
population_specificity: Computational modeling (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antiproliferative efficacy and target modulatory potential (HYAL and ODC) of myricetin 3-rhamnoside on breast cancer cell lines.
results_summary: Myricetin 3-rhamnoside significantly retarded the growth of MDA-MB-231 cells, induced G0/G1 phase arrest, and showed robust binding and inhibition of HYAL and ODC, with a more prominent effect on HYAL in cell-based assays. Computational analysis suggested it is a safe molecule.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cell lines (MDA-MB-231).
effective_dosage: IC50 values: 88.64 ± 7.14 µM (SRB assay), 56.26 ± 8.50 µM (MTT assay).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of Myricetin on intervertebral disc degeneration by examining its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties in nucleus pulposus cells and in a rat model of IDD.
results_summary: Myricetin attenuated IL-1β-induced inflammation and ECM degradation in NPCs by blocking NF-κB signaling and activating Nrf2. In vivo, Myricetin administration ameliorated IDD progression in rats.
population_specificity: Rat nucleus pulposus cells and experimental rat models of intervertebral disc degeneration.
effective_dosage: In vitro: 0, 5, 10, 15, 20 μM for 24h; in vivo: 20 mg/kg intraperitoneally.
study_duration: 24 hours in vitro; duration in vivo not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the therapeutic potential of Myricetin in treating neurological, neuropsychiatric, and neurodegenerative disorders.
results_summary: Myricetin demonstrated antioxidant, antimicrobial, antidiabetic, and neuroprotective effects, including suppression of ROS, lipid peroxidation, and inflammatory markers. It improved insulin function, modulated neurochemicals, reduced MAO expression, and showed protective effects against amyloid-beta and other neurotoxins.
population_specificity: Stressed animals (specific species not mentioned) and implied human relevance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-hyperuricemic efficacy of a hybrid compound (MNH) derived from myricetin and nobiletin, focusing on its effects on serum uric acid levels, renal damage, gut microbiota, and metabolic pathways.
results_summary: MNH significantly reduced serum uric acid, creatinine, and urea nitrogen levels, outperforming myricetin and nobiletin alone. It also repaired renal damage, modulated gut microbiota, and regulated key metabolic pathways.
population_specificity: Yeast paste-induced hyperuricemic mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a chitosan-based nanoplatform delivering myricetin for treating cerebral and hepatic ischemia by targeting ROS and inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that the nanoplatform effectively delivered myricetin, which demonstrated antioxidation, anti-inflammatory effects via macrophage polarization, and endothelial injury repair in ischemic conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (preclinical study, likely animal models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the biological function of myricetin, particularly its effects on cell senescence and mitochondrial function in nucleus pulposus-derived mesenchymal stem cells (NPMSCs) under oxidative stress.
results_summary: Myricetin showed no cytotoxicity at concentrations up to 100 μM and protected NPMSCs against H₂O₂-induced apoptosis, mitochondrial dysfunction, and cell senescence by modulating the SIRT1/PGC-1α pathway. The protective effects were reversed by the SIRT1 inhibitor EX527.
population_specificity: Nucleus pulposus-derived mesenchymal stem cells (NPMSCs) isolated from 4-month-old Sprague-Dawley rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myricetin could inhibit SOD1 aggregation, a key factor in ALS, and assess its potential as a therapeutic agent.
results_summary: Myricetin was found to stabilize SOD1, destabilize preformed fibrils, and reduce fibril elongation in a dose-dependent manner, with experimental evidence supporting its anti-amyloidogenic effects.
population_specificity: In vitro and computational models (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review Myricetin's role in cancer management, focusing on its mechanisms of action, synergistic effects with existing drugs, and approaches to improve bioavailability.
results_summary: Myricetin shows potential in cancer prevention by modulating angiogenesis, inflammation, cell cycle arrest, and apoptosis, and enhances the efficacy of other anticancer drugs. However, challenges like poor bioavailability and the need for nanoformulations remain.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies reviewed).
interactions: Synergistic effects with other anticancer drugs mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the multiple effects of myricetin on targets of T2DM treatment, comparing its efficacy with other flavonoids.
results_summary: Myricetin was found to prevent/suppress hyperglycemia by inhibiting saccharide digestion/uptake and enhancing insulin secretion, possibly as a GLP-1 receptor agonist. It also ameliorated T2DM-related complications by protecting endothelial cells from hyperglycemia-induced oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Not specified (general T2DM context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Myricetin's potential to combat S. aureus-induced osteomyelitis by examining its effects on bone destruction, inflammatory markers, and biofilm formation.
results_summary: Myricetin reduced bone destruction, decreased levels of inflammatory markers (CRP, IL-6, IL-1β), suppressed MAPK pathway activation, and exhibited anti-biofilm effects. In silico docking suggested strong binding affinity with MAPK protein.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice with S. aureus-induced osteomyelitis and MC3T3-E1 cells for in vitro studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Myricetin's therapeutic effects on Alzheimer's disease (AD) and explore its mechanism of action, particularly its role in inhibiting the P38 MAPK pathway and regulating mitochondrial-NLRP3 inflammasome-microglia interactions.
results_summary: Myricetin improved memory loss, spatial learning ability, and reduced Aβ plaque deposition and neuronal damage in AD mice by inhibiting the P38 MAPK pathway, modulating microglial activation, restoring mitochondrial balance, and suppressing NLRP3 inflammasome-driven neuroinflammation. In vitro experiments confirmed P38 MAPK's regulatory role in these processes.
population_specificity: Triple transgenic mice (3 × Tg-AD) as AD models and Aβ25-35-induced BV2 cells for in vitro studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the anticancer properties of myricetin, including its bioactivities, mechanisms of action, and potential as a plant-derived bioactive compound for cancer prevention and treatment.
results_summary: Myricetin exhibits anti-inflammatory, anticancer, apoptosis-inducing, and anticarcinogenic properties, inhibiting cancer cell proliferation in various malignancies such as colon, breast, prostate, bladder, and pancreatic cancers. The review highlights its promise as a bioactive agent but also notes challenges in its development as an anticancer drug.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies on myricetin's effects on cancer cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myricetin exhibits synergistic effects with antibiotics against bacterial strains, particularly focusing on overcoming antimicrobial resistance.
results_summary: The study found that myricetin showed a synergistic interaction only with levofloxacin, suggesting limited but specific potential in enhancing antibiotic efficacy against certain bacteria.
population_specificity: Standard bacterial strains (Escherichia coli ATCC 25922, Klebsiella pneumoniae ATCC 700603, Pseudomonas aeruginosa ATCC 9027, Staphylococcus aureus ATCC 29213, and Staphylococcus aureus ATCC 43300).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic effects and metabolic regulation mechanisms of myricetin in protecting against cardiac injury caused by high-intensity exercise in mice.
results_summary: Myricetin improved cardiac function, reduced myocardial injury markers, alleviated ultrastructural damage, decreased ischemia/hypoxia area, and increased CX43 content. Potential therapeutic targets (PTGS2, MAOB, MAP2K1, EGFR) and metabolic networks were identified and validated.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to high-intensity exercise.
study_duration: 1 week of high-intensity exercise after intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Myricetin could protect against hypoxic-ischemic brain injury by reducing oxidative stress and apoptosis via the NRF2 signaling pathway.
results_summary: Myricetin significantly reduced brain infarction volume, glia activation, apoptosis, and oxidative stress markers by activating NRF2 and increasing downstream proteins NQO-1 and HO-1, effects reversed by the NRF2 inhibitor ML385.
population_specificity: Neonatal rats with hypoxic-ischemic brain damage and CoCl2-induced PC12 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether myricetin could protect against arsenic-induced cardiotoxicity in rats by reducing oxidative stress and restoring antioxidant systems.
results_summary: Myricetin pretreatment inhibited arsenic-induced increases in cardiac damage markers (LDH, AST, CK-MB, LPO) and enhanced antioxidant levels (TAC, TTM). It also improved histopathological changes in cardiac tissue.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to arsenic-induced cardiotoxicity.
effective_dosage: 1 mg/kg and 2 mg/kg, administered intraperitoneally 30 minutes before arsenic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a highly sensitive fluorescence probe using N-doped carbon quantum dots (N-CDs) for detecting myricetin in vine tea.
results_summary: The N-CDs demonstrated excellent linear fluorescence response for myricetin detection in concentrations of 0.2-40 μM and 56-112 μM, with a low detection limit of 56 nM. The probe showed high accuracy in spiked vine tea samples, with recoveries ranging from 98.8% to 101.2%.
population_specificity: Vine tea samples (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory activity of myricetin (MYR) and its nanocomposite against growth and α-hemolysin of C. perfringens isolated from beef and chicken sources.
results_summary: MYR-loaded ZnO/PVA nanocomposite showed strong antimicrobial activity against C. perfringens with MICs ranging from 0.125 to 2 µg/mL, and significantly down-regulated α-hemolysin expression. MYR alone or in nanocomposite form showed no cytotoxicity on chicken red blood cells.
population_specificity: C. perfringens isolates from beef meat and chicken sources.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Myricetin (MYR) could counteract hydrogen peroxide-induced senescence in nucleus pulposus cells (NPCs) and identify potential molecular mechanisms involved.
results_summary: MYR significantly reversed hydrogen peroxide-induced senescence in NPCs by reducing SA-β-gal activity, lowering expression of senescence markers (p21, p16), and decreasing inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL-8). RNA-seq identified SERPINE1 as a key gene mediating MYR's anti-aging effects, with its silencing or overexpression influencing senescence outcomes.
population_specificity: In vitro nucleus pulposus cells (NPCs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myricetin could overcome imatinib resistance in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) by evaluating its efficacy and mechanism of action in resistant CML cells and xenograft models.
results_summary: Myricetin demonstrated potent efficacy in imatinib-resistant CML stem/progenitor and bulk cells, with reduced toxicity in normal bone marrow. It inhibited eIF4E phosphorylation and reduced c-Myc and Cyclin D1 protein levels, confirming its mechanism of action in CML.
population_specificity: Imatinib-resistant CML CD34+ stem/progenitor cells, bulk CML cells, and xenograft mouse models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the combination of Myricetin (Myr) and Cucurbitacin E (CuE) from Citrullus colocynthis could treat non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) by targeting autophagy.
results_summary: The combination (CuMy-12) inhibited A549 cell proliferation, induced apoptosis, and caused cell cycle arrest in the G0/G1 phase. It also suppressed autophagy and the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway, demonstrating a synergistic effect.
population_specificity: A549 human lung adenocarcinoma cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Myricetin at 20 µM combined with Cucurbitacin E at 0.5 µM (CuMy-12).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role and potential mechanisms of myricetin in treating autoimmune myocarditis by modulating immune response and inflammation.
results_summary: Myricetin significantly alleviated myocardial injury in EAM mice, reduced serum anti-cardiac myosin antibodies, IgG, IgM levels, and Th17 cells, while increasing Treg cells. It also inhibited myosin-specific T cell proliferation and suppressed MCP-1, p-p65, p-c-Jun, and Act1/TRAF6/TAK1 expressions in cardiomyocytes and myocardial tissues.
population_specificity: Mice with experimental autoimmune myocarditis (EAM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myricetin could act as a neuroprotective agent in ischemic stroke by reducing neuronal apoptosis through the MAPK-ERK signaling pathway.
results_summary: Myricetin reduced neuronal apoptosis in both in vivo and in vitro models of ischemic stroke, alleviating excitotoxicity, oxidative stress, and inflammation-induced apoptosis. It also improved neuronal intrinsic apoptosis by inhibiting ERK phosphorylation under oxygen and glucose deprivation.
population_specificity: In vivo models (middle cerebral artery occlusion) and in vitro neuronal cultures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-tumor activity of myricetin derivatives, particularly S4-10, against human non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) A549 cells.
results_summary: The study found that S4-10, a myricetin derivative, significantly inhibited A549 cell proliferation, migration, and invasiveness while inducing apoptosis and G2 cycle arrest. It also suggested that S4-10 acts through the sterol biosynthetic-cell apoptosis axis.
population_specificity: Human non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) A549 cells (in vitro and in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the combined anti-diabetic effect of kaempferol and myricetin in STZ-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: The study found that combined treatment with kaempferol and myricetin restored glucose levels, inflammatory cytokines, oxidative markers, and lipid and liver enzymes in diabetic rats, suggesting therapeutic potential for diabetes.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with STZ-induced diabetes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pharmacokinetic behavior and tissue distribution of M10 (a myricetin derivative) in normal and colitis-induced mice, as well as its metabolism via fecal microbiota.
results_summary: M10 and myricetin were primarily distributed in the gastrointestinal tract, with higher levels in inflamed tissues. Fecal microbiota metabolized 80% of M10 into myricetin, which was not absorbed into circulation but localized in inflamed submucosal tissues to prevent colitis development.
population_specificity: Mice (normal and dextran-sodium-sulfate-induced colitis models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of natural myricetin and its derivatives as inhibitors for treating breast and lung cancer using computational drug-design approaches.
results_summary: The study found that myricetin derivatives had better docking scores than standard chemotherapeutic agents (epirubicin hydrochloride and carboplatin) for breast and lung cancer. Additionally, most derivatives were highly soluble in water and free from AMES toxicity, hepatotoxicity, and skin sensitization, except for ligands 1 and 7.
population_specificity: Computational study (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myricetin could improve lipid metabolism, reduce oxidative stress, and mitigate inflammation in hepatocytes exposed to high fatty acid concentrations.
results_summary: Myricetin at 50 and 100 μM reduced TAG, NEFA, oxidative stress markers (MDA, H2O2), and inflammatory markers (SREBF1, NF-κB), while increasing antioxidant activity (SOD) and mitochondrial FA oxidation (CPT1A). These effects suggest myricetin may alleviate lipotoxicity and metabolic stress in hepatocytes.
population_specificity: Primary calf hepatocytes from three healthy female calves (1 day old, 42–48 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential interactors and biological functions of myricetin in colorectal cancer and synthesize silver nanoparticles labeled with myricetin to assess its anticancer effects.
results_summary: Myricetin demonstrated efficacy in killing human colorectal cancer cell lines, with in-silico analysis suggesting its potential as a promising herbal treatment. The study utilized various techniques to confirm myricetin's effects, including gene expression analysis and morphological monitoring.
population_specificity: Human colorectal cancer cell lines

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticancer effects of Myricetin (MYR) on triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), focusing on its mechanisms and impacts on metastasis, particularly targeting the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway.
results_summary: MYR induced early and late apoptotic cell death and inhibited cell proliferation in TNBC cells. It modulated cell cycle, pro-angiogenic, and invasion effects via MAPK and PI3K/AKT signaling pathways and regulated multiple other signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiviral activity of Myricetin against pseudorabies virus (PRV) and its potential as an anti-herpesvirus drug.
results_summary: Myricetin showed potent antiviral activity against PRV, with a suppression rate of 96.4% at 500 μM and an IC50 of 42.69 μM. It inhibited viral adsorption, penetration, and replication, activated host antiviral defenses, and improved survival rates and reduced viral loads in PRV-infected mice.
population_specificity: In vitro cell studies and PRV-infected mouse model.
effective_dosage: 500 μM in cells; dosage in mice not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether myricetin could ameliorate atopic dermatitis (AD) symptoms and skin lesions in obese mice and explore its mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Myricetin topical administration improved AD symptoms in obese mice, reducing dermatitis scores, scratching behavior, epidermal thickness, and mast cell infiltration. It also modulated immune responses, restored skin barrier function, and inhibited inflammatory pathways.
population_specificity: Obese mice with induced AD-like lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myricetin could mitigate atrazine-induced reproductive dysfunction in rats by examining its effects on hormonal levels, sperm quality, and oxidative stress markers.
results_summary: Myricetin improved hormonal levels (testosterone, FSH, LH), sperm count and motility, and reduced oxidative stress and histological damage in atrazine-exposed rats. It showed dose-dependent protective effects without altering testicular sperm number or viability.
population_specificity: Male rats exposed to atrazine

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Myricetin (MYR) could improve memory impairment, reduce neuroinflammation, and enhance neurotrophic factors in sleep-deprived rats.
results_summary: MYR administration significantly improved cognitive and spatial memory deficits in sleep-deprived rats, reduced neuroinflammation linked to NF-κB activation, and increased BDNF expression in the hippocampus.
population_specificity: Sleep-deprived rats
